WRITING.TITLE: Overthewire Bandit: Passwords not working?
WRITING.TEXT:
The passwords I'm getting for bandit aren't working. I can log into bandit0 with the password "bandit0" but I'm not getting any further. I tried copy-pasting the password from the readme, then I tried plugging it in manually, but both gave me "access denied." I even looked up the solutions online and tried to log into bandit2 and bandit3, but both times I just got "access denied."
Clearly I'm doing something wrong here, since the passwords seem to work for everyone else, but I have no idea what it is. Advice/tips/solutions?
EDIT: Well I slept on it, tried again, and the problem seems to have disappeared. Weird.
Still, that's a pretty damn good rate. It probably survives the attack, and then you've got a *1/4 for 1*. That's excellent value for a one-drop.

If a person has only a surface-level faith, then the deeper differences between, say, Methodism and Catholicism will be lost on them. A 6-year-old is going to get the same spiritual benefit out of a protestant sermon as a Catholic homily.
It's only when you're mature enough to understand the nuances that these differences begin to matter. And many adults that claim to be religious don't really have a mature relationship with Christ.

I like to make fun of protestants, but it's always lighthearted and I don't mean anything by it. For the most part, protestants are our brothers and sisters in Christ. Unless they have a strong, deep relationship with Christ, the differences between protestantism and Catholicism are minute and, frankly, insignificant. It doesn't mean anything more to go through the motions of Catholicism than to go through the motions of protestantism.
That said, it's not as though protestants are wholly equal in the truth of their beliefs. Protestantism rejects the tradition and apostolic succession of the mother Church, and rejects the Pope as the Vicar of Christ. The greatest issue with protestantism is that it completely rejects the *best* institution we have to help us find the truth about God: the Church. It hasn't been perfect, and at times it has been corrupt, but the Church is always more reliable than the judgement of one man. That's humbling to admit, and difficult, but it's true.
As for major protestant reformers: Martin Luther I have a lot of respect for, he brought up some good points and rather than denouncing 1000+ years of tradition he asked to see them debated *within* the Church. I can't say I approve of running off to form his own faith, but I can respect his initial attempts to reform the Catholic church.

I'm a college Sophomore now, and I've noticed two distinct differences:
1. The level of competition is MUCH higher. A lot of these other kids are Poli Sci or International Relations majors, they often have access to some incredibly specific and in-depth research on the topics at hand.
2. Delegates in crisis committees seem to be a lot more concerned with their *character's* power than their own. That is, in High School MUN all the "power moves" were about giving yourself more portfolio powers, more options when responding to crises, and generally it was more about appearing to be the most powerful delegate in the room. In college, a lot of delegates are content making their crisis notes all about how much money they're embezzling from the committee. The result is that they send tons of crisis notes that have little to no actual impact on the committee until they tell you about it afterwards. It's... weird. I'm still not used to it.
Absolutely, he's the most fun character in Twelfth Night. I've played him twice and I can tell you from experience that he's a lot of fun to be.

WRITING.TITLE: [Standard] Mizzium Meddler against Bant CoCo?
WRITING.TEXT:
[[Mizzium Meddler]] doesn't really see play, but I feel like it's enormously strong against Bant CoCo. Bant mainboards 2 removal spells: [[Dromoka's Command]] and [[Reflector Mage]]. Mizzium Meddler is an effective counter to both.
Against Reflector Mage, you flash in Meddler to eat the bounce and then you have it in hand to play during your opponent's next turn.
Dromoka's has 2 possible ways to target a creature you control: Add a +1/+1 counter, and fight a creature. If the opponent tries to use the former to buff a creature, you can flash in Meddler and redirect the counter to it. If the opponent tries to use the latter, you can play Meddler and save your creature. Meddler probably survives the fight too, with 4 toughness.
Mizzium Meddler seems like an awesome card against Bant CoCo, but I'm not positive what deck it could fit into though. UB Zombies doesn't need it. I hate to say it, but I think it's best fit would be in the Bant CoCo SB for the mirror match. Thoughts?
The blood of the covenant is thicker than the water of the womb.

WRITING.TITLE: Sometimes when I can't get something to work, I get someone else to watch me try do that when I succeed I look stupid. Is there a term for this?
WRITING.TEXT: Like, for example, I couldn't get my power washer to turn on. I turned the dial, pressed the button, and nothing happened. So I brought my supervisor over to watch me. I tried again, the exact same thing, and it turned on. I did this out of the superstitious belief that if success will make me look foolish, I'll succeed. I've been calling it "fool's debugging." Is there an actual term for this?
Oh, I'm so sorry Mr. /u/_BEUFORD_. Please forgive me. I didn't mean to imply that I give a fuck what you think about me. Please, accept my sincerest apology.

WRITING.TITLE: I think I picked the wrong major. Again.
WRITING.TEXT:
So my first choice major was Comp Sci, with Physics as my second choice. I was rejected for cs and majored in Physics for a year. Then I applied for a transfer to CS with Computer Engineering as a second choice. Again, rejected, so now I'm in computer engineering.
I'm now discovering that CPE is all hardware and almost no software. Worse, I'm gradually realizing that it's possible to get a job without majoring in engineering. WHY DID NO ONE TELL ME THIS?! I've always been told that STEM = employment, non-STEM = unemployment. I like programming, but if I had known that there was a market for Political Science majors, that's what I'd be doing!
But I can't really change course now. All my friends are tech people, and I've got a few promising opportunities for CS internships next summer. All my professional connections are USELESS if I want a government/legal job. I've got to slog through 3 more years of computer engineering so I can get into law school and do what I really want to.
And on top of it all, I don't even like the school I'm in. There's another school closer to home that has an excellent poli sci program AND a great CS program. The school I'm in now doesn't have any of the extra curriculars that I'm interested in.
I'll see what I can do about making a screenshot album. I'm very proud of my work there and I think it turned out real well.

If you want to be Bottom, ask to read for every character. All the men, all the women, all the lovers, all the faeries.
Jokes aside, I just closed a production of Midsummer last week (I was Bottom). I find it to be one of Shakespeare's most difficult works to understand and convey. In particular, the faeries always speak in a convoluted verse that makes the wording awkward to convey without singing "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star." Bottom requires very good comedic timing, and I found I had to practice and recite the scenes to myself over and over to get it right. But it's also an extremely rewarding role, because you can't *overdo* Bottom. There is no limit to the amount of energy and enthusiasm you put into the role. The hammier, the better, full stop. Good luck!

Absolutely. These questions have answers, but they're so polarizing and so politicized that it's nigh impossible to approach them objectively. Which saddens me, because if we don't fully know what the facts are, we can't form comprehensive solutions.

On the flipside, we can't just dismiss biological determinism as an explaination because we fear being labeled as "racist." The reason that we *know* Africans are not genetically inferior to Europeans is that we ran a bunch of experiments with that hypothesis and, by and large, they rejected it. The only reason we can be so confident that Africans and Europeans are not genetically disposed to failure and success is that we were willing to ask the question.

That question doesn't have a simple answer, because of how many variables are at play here. Does this man feel that sex is a deeply emotional connection, or a simple act of pleasure? Does the man live in a culture where sex is taboo, or a more open society? How attractive is this man? How many women does he see every day? How high is his sex drive?
And after you take all *that* into consideration, it's still a matter of chance as to whether this man meets someone with whom he shares mutual attraction.
Half of it is extremely personal to each individual, and the other half is pure chance. You can't realistically compare your anecdotal experiences to anyone else's.

WRITING.TITLE: I got my first job two days ago, and I'm quitting today
WRITING.TEXT:
I just got this job for a moving company two days ago. I figured it would be a good way to occupy my time and make some money for school. I enjoy physical labor too, so all in all I was really looking forward to this.
Now I'm kind of an attention whore, but for the first time in my life I genuinely just wanted to keep my head down and do the work. So, naturally, I make a fool of myself a dozen times before we finish training. My grip strength is poor, my balance sucks, I have terrible form, etc, etc. I can't do this job. It's more physically difficult than I am capable of.
The other guys were nothing but encouraging and helpful, assuring me that even if I was "the runt of the litter," I was still "part of the family."
But I can't keep doing this for another week. I thought I could stick around until Friday, so I could be sure I was paid first, but I don't know if I can do it. So after I clock out today, I'm quitting.
I feel like shit about it. My first job and I'm not even capable of performing it. I've never been particularly strong, I don't work out regularly, but I've never been "out of shape." 2 years ago I biked 250 miles in a week, and I've only gotten stronger since. But this job is too much. I don't have the balance to carry a dresser twice my size without falling over. I don't have the grip strength to carry boxes that weigh 80% of my body weight.
I think the worst part about it is how *nice* everyone is about it. I'm this scrawny, upper-middle-class white kid surrounded by bulky working class guys, but they haven't complained about me not being able to lift as much. They've accepted me, given me good advice. If someone had been an asshole to me at least I would be angry. At least I would have someone to channel all my bad feelings towards. Instead, I have no one to blame but myself.
Endrant. Sorry for the novel.
EDIT: I broke 50 lbs of ceramic plates today, so I quit this morning. I was only planning on doing this for ~3 weeks until I go back to college, but I think if I try to move any more expensive stuff I'll be losing more than I'm earning.
